ol.li: Learn to view a matrix geometrically as a function.
Learn examples of matrix transformations: reflection, dilation, rotation, shear, projection.
Understand the vocabulary surrounding transformations: domain, codomain, range.
Understand the domain, codomain, and range of a matrix transformation.
Vocabulary words: transformation / function, domain, codomain, range, identity transformation, matrix transformation.

introduction.p: In this section we learn to understand matrices geometrically as functions, or transformations. We briefly discuss transformations in general, then specialize to matrix transformations, which are transformations that come from matrices.

subsection.title: Matrices as Functions
subsection.p: Informally, a function is a rule that accepts inputs and produces outputs. For instance, f(x) = x^2 is a function that accepts one number x as its input, and outputs the square of that number: f(2) = 4. In this subsection, we interpret matrices as functions.

subsection.title: Transformations
subsection.p: At this point it is convenient to fix our ideas and terminology regarding functions, which we will call transformations in this book. This allows us to systematize our discussion of matrices as functions.

statement.p:
A transformation from \R^n to \R^m is a rule T that assigns to each vector x in \R^n a vector T(x) in \R^m.
\R^n is called the domain of T.
\R^m is called the codomain of T.
For x in \R^n, the vector T(x) in \R^m is the image of x under T.
The set of all images \{T(x)\mid x\text{ in }\R^n\} is the range of T.
The notation T\colon\R^n\To\R^m means T is a transformation from \R^n to \R^m.

subsection.p: The range of T is the set of all vectors in the codomain that actually arise as outputs of the function T, for some input. In other words, the range is all vectors b in the codomain such that T(x)=b has a solution x in the domain.

example.title: A Function of one variable
example.p:
Most of the functions you may have seen previously have domain and codomain equal to \R = \R^1. For example, \sin\colon\R\To\R \qquad \sin(x) = \left(\,\parbox{5cm}{ the length of the opposite edge over the hypotenuse of a right triangle with angle $x$ in radians}\,\right).
Notice that we have defined \sin by a rule: a function is defined by specifying what the output of the function is for any possible input.
Note that the range of \sin is the interval [-1,1]: this is the set of all possible outputs of the \sin function.

example.title: Functions of several variables
example.p: Here is an example of a function from \R^2 to \R^3: f\vec{x y} = \vec{x+y \cos(y) y-x^2}. The inputs of f each have two entries, and the outputs have three entries. In this case, we have defined f by a formula, so we evaluate f by substituting values for the variables: f\vec{2 3} = \vec{2+3 \cos(3) 3-2^2} = \vec{5 \cos(3) -1}.

Here is an example of a function from \R^3 to \R^3: f(v) = \left(\,\parbox{5.5cm}{the counterclockwise rotation of $v$ by an angle of $42^\circ$ about the $z$-axis}\,\right). In other words, f takes a vector with three entries, then rotates it; hence the ouput of f also has three entries. In this case, we have defined f by a geometric rule.

statement.p: The identity transformation \Id_{\R^n}\colon\R^n\to\R^n is the transformation defined by the rule \Id_{\R^n}(x) = x \qquad\text{for all $x$ in $\R^n$}.

subsection.p: In other words, the identity transformation does not move its input vector: the output is the same as the input. Its domain and codomain are both \R^n, and its range is \R^n as well, since every vector in \R^n is the output of itself.

example.title: A real-word transformation: robotics
example.p: The definition of transformation and its associated vocabulary may seem quite abstract, but transformations are extremely common in real life. Here is an example from the fields of robotics and computer graphics.

It is relatively straightforward to find a formula for f(\theta,\phi,\psi) using some basic trigonometry. If you want the robot to fetch your coffee cup, however, you have to find the angles \theta,\phi,\psi that will put the hand at the position of your beverage. It is not at all obvious how to do this, and it is not even clear if the answer is unique! You can ask yourself: which positions on the table can my robot arm reach? or what is the arms range of motion? This is the same as asking: what is the range of f?

Unfortunately, this kind of function does not come from a matrix, so one cannot use linear algebra to answer these kinds of questions. In fact, these functions are rather complicated; their study is the subject of inverse kinematics.

subsection.title: Matrix Transformations
subsection.p: Now we specialize the general notions and vocabulary from the previous to the functions defined by matrices that we considered in the first .

statement.p:
Let A be an m\times n matrix. The matrix transformation associated to A is the transformation
T\colon \R^n\To\R^m \sptxt{defined by} T(x) = Ax.
This is the transformation that takes a vector x in \R^n to the vector Ax in \R^m.

subsection.p: If A has n columns, then it only makes sense to multiply A by vectors with n entries. This is why the domain of T(x)=Ax is \R^n. If A has n rows, then Ax has m entries for any vector x in \R^n; this is why the codomain of T(x)=Ax is \R^m.

Suppose that A has columns v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n. If we multiply A by a general vector x, we get
Ax = \mat{| | ,, |; v_1 v_2 \cdots, v_n; | | ,, |}\vec{x_1 x_2 \vdots, x_n} = x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_nv_n.
This is just a general linear combination of v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n. Therefore, the outputs of T(x) = Ax are exactly the linear combinations of the columns of A: the range of T is the column space of A. See this .

bluebox.p:
Let A be an m\times n matrix, and let T(x)=Ax be the associated matrix transformation.
The domain of T is \R^n, where n is the number of columns of A.
The codomain of T is \R^m, where m is the number of rows of A.
The range of T is the column space of A.

example.title: Interactive: A 2\times 3 matrix: reprise
example.p:
Let
A = \mat{1 -1 2; -2 2 4},
and define T(x) = Ax. The domain of T is \R^3, and the codomain is \R^2. The range of T is the column space; since all three columns are collinear, the range is a line in \R^2.

figure.caption: A picture of the matrix transformation T. The input vector is x, which is a vector in \R^3, and the output vector is b=T(x)=Ax, which is a vector in \R^2. The violet line on the right is the range of T; as you vary x, the output b is constrained to lie on this line.

example.title: Interactive: A 3\times 2 matrix: reprise
example.p:
Let
A = \mat{1 0; 0 1; 1 0},
and define T(x) = Ax. The domain of T is \R^2, and the codomain is \R^3. The range of T is the column space; since A has two columns which are not collinear, the range is a plane in \R^3.

figure.caption: A picture of the matrix transformation T. The input vector is x, which is a vector in \R^2, and the output vector is b=T(x)=Ax, which is a vector in \R^3. The violet plane on the right is the range of T; as you vary x, the output b is constrained to lie on this plane.

statement.p: Let A = \mat{1 0 0; 0 1 0; 0 0 0}, and let T(x) = Ax. What are the domain, the codomain, and the range of T?

solution.p: Be careful not to confuse the codomain with the range here. The range is a plane, but it is a plane in \R^3, so the codomain is still \R^3. The outputs of T all have three entries; the last entry is simply always zero.

subsection.p: In the case of an n\times n square matrix, the domain and codomain of T(x) = Ax are both \R^n. In this situation, one can regard T as operating on \R^n: it moves the vectors around in the same space.

example.title: Matrix transformations of \R^2

statement.p:
Let
A = \mat{1 1; 0 1; 1 1},
and let T(x)=Ax, so T\colon\R^2\to\R^3 is a matrix transformation.
Evaluate T(u) for u=\vec{3 4}.
Let
b = \vec{7 5 7}.
Find a vector v in \R^2 such that T(v)=b. Is there more than one?
Does there exist a vector w in \R^3 such that there is more than one v in \R^2 with T(v)=w?
Find a vector w in \R^3 which is not in the range of T.

Note: all of the above questions are intrinsic to the transformation T: they make sense to ask whether or not T is a matrix transformation. See the next . As T is in fact a matrix transformation, all of these questions will translate into questions about the corresponding matrix A.

ol.li:
We evaluate T(u) by substituting the definition of T in terms of matrix multiplication:
T\vec{3 4} = \mat{1 1; 0 1; 1 1}\vec{3 4} = \vec{7 4 7}.

Translation: is there any vector w in \R^3 such that the solution set of Av=w has more than one vector in it? The solution set of Ax=w, if non-empty, is a translate of the solution set of Av=b above, which has one vector in it. See this . It follows that the solution set of Av=w can have at most one vector.

statement.p:
Define a transformation T\colon\R^2\to\R^3 by the formula
T\vec{x y} = \vec{\ln(x) \cos(y) \ln(x)}.
Evaluate T(u) for u=\vec{1 \pi}.
Let
b = \vec{7 1 7}.
Find a vector v in \R^2 such that T(v)=b. Is there more than one?
Does there exist a vector w in \R^3 such that there is more than one v in \R^2 with T(v)=w?
Find a vector w in \R^3 which is not in the range of T.

Note: we asked (almost) the exact same questions about a matrix transformation in the previous . The point of this example is to illustrate the fact that the questions make sense for a transformation that has no hope of coming from a matrix. In this case, these questions do not translate into questions about a matrix; they have to be answered in some other way.

ol.li:
We evaluate T(u) using the defining formula:
T\vec{1 \pi} = \vec{\ln(1) \cos(\pi) \ln(1)} = \vec{0 -1 0}.
The vector b from the previous part is an example of such a vector.
